coder

Erik Bulow

2019-09-03

Source: vignettes/coder.Rmd
coder.Rmd

This vignette will demonstrate the core functionality of the “coder” package by a trivial example.

Car ownership

Let’s assume we have a list of people, as well as dates for their driving license:


library(coder)

people <- 
  data.frame(
    name = c(
      "Gavin, Christopher", "Albrecht, Lauren",
      "Aziz, Emily", "Svenne Petsson"
    ),
    license = as.Date(c(
      "1949-05-23", "2016-03-04", "2014-12-18", "1985-05-04"
    ))
  )

We also have a car registry with car ownership for 1,000 cars (with code_date the date when the car was bought):

head(ex.cars)
#>                  id              code  code_date
#> 1   Medina, Desmand         Mazda RX4 2018-12-13
#> 2 al-Hashem,  Muzna Chrysler Imperial 2017-07-30
#> 3  el-Kaleel, Aadil         Merc 240D 2018-09-20
#> 4    Foster, Amanda    Toyota Corolla 2018-08-08
#> 5     Budy, Cameren     Maserati Bora 2018-09-27
#> 6       Ash, Reilly          Merc 230 2018-09-25

We are not interested in individual brand names of each car, but we want to know who owns a car made by a specific company. We can specify a classification scheme of brands related to each company (a classcodes object). Note that not all models are classified. The classification scheme is made by regular expressions since these are more effective to work with for clasification of large data sets.

ex.carbrands_excars
#>     group                                 regex
#> 1   Mazda                                 Mazda
#> 2 Mer-Ben                                  Merc
#> 3    Ford                          Ford|Lincoln
#> 4    Fiat Chrysler|Fiat|Dodge|Ferrari|Maserati,
#> 5  Toyota                                Toyota
#> 6  Volksw                               Porsche
#> 7   Geely                           Volvo|Lotus

Categorize

We want to know if anyone owns a car frmo a company that we are interested in.

We use the three objects from above:

  • people: the people we are interested in,
  • ex.cars: the centralised car registry and
  • ex.carbrands_excars: the classification of car makers.
(x <- categorize(people, ex.cars, ex.carbrands_excars, id = "name"))
#> index calculated as number of relevant categories
#>                  name    license Mazda Mer-Ben Ford Fiat Toyota Volksw
#> 1:   Albrecht, Lauren 2016-03-04    NA      NA   NA   NA     NA     NA
#> 2:        Aziz, Emily 2014-12-18    NA      NA   NA   NA     NA     NA
#> 3: Gavin, Christopher 1949-05-23    NA      NA   NA   NA     NA     NA
#> 4:     Svenne Petsson 1985-05-04    NA      NA   NA   NA     NA     NA
#>    Geely index
#> 1:    NA    NA
#> 2:    NA    NA
#> 3:    NA    NA
#> 4:    NA    NA

Interpretation

We can see that:

  • Emily Aziz owns a Mazda.
  • Lauren Albrecht owns both a Mercedes and a Toyota.
  • Christopher Gavin might in fact own a car, but none of the ones we are interested in.
  • Svenne Petsson is a Swede and is not found in our American car register.

The index column is here the sum of identified cars owned by each person.

Note that each column identifies if a person owns at least one car from the relevant company.

Cars owned before license

We can use the date columns to check if anyone owned a car already before they got their drivers license. We need to specify that the date column is called license. The days argument specifies that we are interested in cars bought before this date.

(x <- 
   categorize(
     people, 
     ex.cars, 
     ex.carbrands_excars, 
     id = "name", 
     date = "license", 
     days = c(-Inf, -1)
  )
)
#> index calculated as number of relevant categories
#>                  name    license Mazda Mer-Ben Ford Fiat Toyota Volksw
#> 1:   Albrecht, Lauren 2016-03-04    NA      NA   NA   NA     NA     NA
#> 2:        Aziz, Emily 2014-12-18    NA      NA   NA   NA     NA     NA
#> 3: Gavin, Christopher 1949-05-23    NA      NA   NA   NA     NA     NA
#> 4:     Svenne Petsson 1985-05-04    NA      NA   NA   NA     NA     NA
#>    Geely index
#> 1:    NA    NA
#> 2:    NA    NA
#> 3:    NA    NA
#> 4:    NA    NA

Indeed, Lauren bought a car before he were alowed to drive it himself.

Car rating

We are not only interested in the number of cars owned by each individual. We would also like to rate the cars based on the manufacturer. Let us assign some score to each company. We then specifies that the index should be calculated based on the new column named “score”.

ex.carbrands_excars$score <- c(10, 1, 2, 1, 1, 2, 37)

(x <- categorize(people, ex.cars, ex.carbrands_excars, id = "name", ind = "score"))
#>                  name    license Mazda Mer-Ben Ford Fiat Toyota Volksw
#> 1:   Albrecht, Lauren 2016-03-04    NA      NA   NA   NA     NA     NA
#> 2:        Aziz, Emily 2014-12-18    NA      NA   NA   NA     NA     NA
#> 3: Gavin, Christopher 1949-05-23    NA      NA   NA   NA     NA     NA
#> 4:     Svenne Petsson 1985-05-04    NA      NA   NA   NA     NA     NA
#>    Geely score
#> 1:    NA    NA
#> 2:    NA    NA
#> 3:    NA    NA
#> 4:    NA    NA

Even though Emily owns half as many cars as Albrecht, she gets a higher score.

Concluding remark

This vignette illustrates a simple example where the data sets are small, and the codnig schemes are trivial. If that is the case, it might be equally good to just join or merge the data sets manually. A more realistic example of when the package might come handy is presented in the vignette called “Comorbidity”.
